page.title: 09 THE COOMBE HILL CANAL
page.content: THE COOMBE HILL CANAL The Coombe Hill Canal was opened in 1796 from the River Severn at Wainlode to Coombe Hill 4 kilometres away. It ran through the low lying meadows from west to east and effectively divides the rectangle into two and separates the villages of Lower Apperley and The Leigh. It was built to bring coal from the Forest of Dean and the Midlands together with building materials closer to the expanding spa town of Cheltenham, when roads in the Severn Vale were in a very poor condition. It was proposed to extend it to Cheltenham but lack of money prevented this and then the railways were built. The canal still holds water but the lock at the Severn end has been filled in. The wharf and buildings remain at Coombe Hill.
